topic: What responsibilities should tech companies have when collecting and monetizing user data?

statements.persona:
age: 63
sex: Male
race: White alone
ancestry: European
household language: English only

statements.statement: As someone who runs a business, I understand that data can help companies improve their services and stay competitive, but there have to be clear limits and accountability. Tech companies should be required to clearly explain what they’re collecting, get real consent, protect that information like it was their own family’s, and never sell or share it in ways that people didn’t knowingly agree to. I also think there should be firm legal consequences when they misuse data or hide what they’re doing, because ordinary folks deserve basic privacy and honesty in how they’re treated online.

statements.statement: Tech companies should treat our personal data like something sacred, not just another product to sell. They must clearly explain what they’re collecting, get our explicit consent, and be held legally accountable when they misuse or fail to protect it. I’ve seen what happens when governments or powerful groups know too much about people’s private lives, and I don’t trust big corporations any more than I trusted that. Strong rules, real penalties, and minimal data collection should be the standard, not the exception.

statements.statement: As someone who works in healthcare and sees every day how sensitive personal information can be, I believe tech companies should treat user data with the same seriousness we treat medical records: clear consent, strict limits on access, and full transparency about how it’s used and sold. If they profit from our data, they should also be accountable for protecting it, preventing misuse, and giving users real control over what’s collected.

statements.statement: As someone who works hard for a living and values both privacy and fairness, I think tech companies have a responsibility to be completely transparent about what data they collect, how they use it, and who they sell it to. If they’re making money off our information, we should have real control over what’s shared, easy ways to opt out, and strong legal protections against misuse or discrimination—especially for marginalized communities. They shouldn’t be allowed to quietly exploit people’s data in the background just because most folks don’t have time to read a 20-page terms-of-service.

statements.statement: Tech companies have a responsibility to be straight with people about what data they’re collecting and exactly how they’re using it, in plain English, not buried in fine print. If they’re going to make money off our information, there ought to be strict rules and real penalties to keep them from abusing it, just like we have rules for handling evidence or personal records in law enforcement. I may not be tech-savvy, but I know trust is earned, and these companies shouldn’t be allowed to treat our private lives like a free-for-all.

statements.statement: As someone who lives a lot of my life online and loves connecting with new people, I get that data helps tech companies build cool, personalized experiences—but they should never treat our information like a free-for-all resource. They have a responsibility to be radically transparent about what they collect, get clear consent, and give us real control over how our data is used and monetized. If they profit from our data, there should be strict limits, strong privacy protections, and meaningful accountability when they mess up. No one’s digital life should be exploited just because they clicked “agree” on a 30-page terms-of-service they’ll never realistically read.

statements.statement: As someone who works in tech and manages projects for a living, I think companies have a serious responsibility to be transparent and honest about what data they collect, how they use it, and who they share it with. Monetizing user data shouldn’t mean exploiting people’s ignorance—there should be clear consent, strong security safeguards, and strict limits on using data in ways that can harm individuals or families. I’m not against innovation or business growth, but it has to be balanced with respecting people’s privacy and dignity, much like we expect in any other area of life.

statements.statement: As someone who’s seen a lot of change in my lifetime, I think tech companies have a serious responsibility to treat our personal data with the same care they’d give to something fragile and irreplaceable. They shouldn’t be allowed to quietly sell and trade our information behind dense legal language; consent needs to be clear, simple, and genuinely optional. I’m not against companies making money, but if they profit from our data, we deserve strong privacy protections, transparency about how it’s used, and real power to say no—especially for kids and vulnerable people.

statements.statement: As someone who loves new tech but also works every day with vulnerable families, I think tech companies have a serious moral responsibility to treat user data like something deeply personal, not just a commodity. They should be radically transparent about what they collect, get clear and informed consent (no dark patterns), minimize data collection to what’s truly necessary, and build in strong safeguards against misuse or discrimination. If they profit from our data, they should also be accountable—through regulation, audits, and meaningful penalties—when they fail to protect people’s privacy and dignity.

statements.statement: As someone who works the land and depends on healthy ecosystems, I think tech companies should treat our personal data like a shared natural resource—handled carefully, not strip‑mined for quick profit. They should be fully transparent about what they collect, get clear and informed consent, minimize what they store, and never sell or share it in ways that can harm people or communities. Just like we’re expected to follow regulations to protect soil and water, they should be held to strong, enforceable privacy and security standards that put people and the public good ahead of profit.

statements.statement: If these big tech companies are going to collect our data, they ought to be straight with us about what they’re taking, how they’re using it, and give us a real choice to opt out without punishing us for it. They shouldn’t be allowed to sell or share personal information without clear consent, and there ought to be strong laws with real teeth if they lie or get careless and let our data get hacked.

statements.statement: As someone who spent her life as a teacher and still believes deeply in the importance of education and community, I think tech companies have a responsibility to be honest and clear about what data they collect and how they profit from it, in language anyone can understand. They should only collect what is truly necessary, protect it as carefully as they would their own family’s information, and be held accountable when they misuse it. People deserve real choices and control over their data, not tiny print and sneaky settings, and our laws should reflect the dignity and privacy every person is owed.

statements.statement: I think tech companies should have to ask clearly before they use our data, and explain it in words kids and parents can actually understand, not just tiny print. If they make money from our information, they should have to keep it super safe and not sell things that could embarrass or hurt us later. It also feels fair that they give people choices, like easy buttons to turn tracking off, instead of hiding it in confusing menus. Since lots of kids use apps and games, companies should have extra rules about what they can collect from us and for how long.

statements.statement: At my age, I’ve seen too many powerful institutions take advantage of people who didn’t know any better, so tech companies absolutely must be transparent and honest about what data they collect and how they profit from it. They should treat user data like a patient’s medical chart—only gather what’s necessary, protect it diligently, and never share or sell it without clear, informed consent. And because so many older people and immigrants like me can be especially vulnerable, there should be strong legal protections and plain-language explanations so everyone can truly understand and control how their information is used.

statements.statement: I think tech companies should have to clearly tell us what data they’re collecting and exactly how they’re using it, in words that regular people and kids can actually understand. They shouldn’t be allowed to sell or share our information without our real permission, and there should be extra protections for minors so our data can’t be used to mess with us or track us in creepy ways.
